title: Homework 0
text: In this blog, I will be explaining how to construct interesting data visualizations of the Palmer Penguins dataset using Python.

title: Homework 0
text: In this blog, I will be explaining how to construct interesting data visualizations of the Palmer Penguins dataset using Python.

title: Homework 0
text:
Loading Dataset
The dataset can be read into Python by running the following code

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
import seaborn as sns #seaborn library for data visualiazation 

url = "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/pic16b-ucla/24W/main/datasets/palmer_penguins.csv"
penguins = pd.read_csv(url)

title: Homework 0
text:
Bar Chart
In order to create data visualizations, we should first explore the dataset and understand the variables included as well as their relationship. For instance, I have noticed there are different categories of penguins and decided to investigate the distribution of penguins with bar chart.

#countplot function is used for showing the counts of observations in each categorical bin using bars
sns.countplot(x = 'Species', data = penguins)
plt.title('Distribution of Penguin Species')
plt.show()








From the bar chart, we can observe that Adelie has the greatest amount in the sample while Chinstrap has the least amount. However, this is not interesting. We could create more meaningful plots through the quantitative variables of each group.

title: Homework 0
text:
Scatterplot
As flipper length and body mass are both important components for a penguine, I am interested in whether there is any relationship between these two variables. To find such pattern between two quantitative variables, scatterplot is an useful tool.

#sns.scatterplot is a function from the Seaborn library in Python, used for creating scatterplots
sns.scatterplot(x='Flipper Length (mm)', y='Body Mass (g)', hue='Species', data=penguins)
plt.title('Flipper Length vs Body Mass by Species')
plt.show()








From the graph, we can oberve that there exists a positive correlations between flipper length and body mass in all three species, while the correlation strength could be explored further.

title: Homework 0
text:
Histogram
A histogram could also be used to represent the distribution of a numerical dataset, especially when we want to compare distribution of a variable across different groups. From the above scatterplot, We can see that both flipper length and body mass vary across different groups such that we can use histogram to find the distribution.

plt.figure(figsize=(14, 6))
plt.subplot(1, 2, 1) 
#sns.histplot is a function from the Seaborn library used to create histograms. 
sns.histplot(data=penguins, x='Body Mass (g)', hue='Species', element='step', palette='Set2')
plt.title('Histogram of Body Mass (g) by Species')
plt.ylabel('Frequency') 
plt.show()








From the histogram of body mass(g) by species, we can observe that Gentoo has greater body mass than Adelie and Chinstrap in general

plt.figure(figsize=(14, 6))
plt.subplot(1, 2, 1) 
#sns.histplot is a function from the Seaborn library used to create histograms. 
sns.histplot(data=penguins, x='Flipper Length (mm)', hue='Species', element='step', palette='Set2')
plt.title('Histogram of Flipper Length (mm) by Species')
plt.ylabel('Frequency') 
plt.show()








From the histogram of flipper length (mm) by species, we can observe that Gentoo has greater flipper length than Adelie and Chinstrap in general as well.

title: Homework 0
text:
Boxplot
In addition, we can also understand the distribution of data through boxplot, which is a standardized way of displaying the distribution based on a five-number summary: minimum, first quartile (Q1), median, third quartile (Q3), and maximum. For instance, we can investigate the culmen length of each group through box plot.

plt.figure(figsize=(6, 6))
#sns.boxplot is a function in the Seaborn library used to create boxplots. 
sns.boxplot(x='Species', y='Culmen Length (mm)', data=penguins, palette='Set1')
plt.title('Boxplot of Culmen Length (mm) by Species')
plt.show()








From the boxplot, we can observe that Chinstrap has the greatest median among three species such that we could conclude that Chinstrap has the greatest culmen length compared to the other two species. Meanwhile, Adelie has the least median such that it has the least culmen length overall.
